item.title: Shopee Malaysia is showing support for breast cancer awareness by going pink
item.description:
Shopee, a popular online marketplace in Malaysia, is partnering with the Pink Ribbon Deeds (PRIDE) Foundation for a “Goes Pink” campaign throughout October to raise awareness about breast cancer. The campaign involves both online and offline initiatives. Shopee’s “Goes Pink” collection features pink and white products across various categories like mobile accessories, beauty products, and home goods, encouraging users to purchase and show their support. With over 2 million app installs in Malaysia, Shopee aims to leverage its platform to spread awareness nationwide...

item.title: Reduce the risk of cancer in your workplace with International SOS
item.description:
International SOS has used World Cancer Day to highlight the impact of cancer on the workplace and encourage companies to take action. They emphasize that many cancer cases are preventable and point out that workplaces can contribute to cancer risk factors like unhealthy habits and exposure to harmful substances. The organization’s Medical Director, Dr. Kate O’Reilly, stressed the growing impact of cancer on the workforce, stating that it affects not just the individual but the entire organization...

item.title: Go on a date with some dried fruit
item.description:
Studies suggest that dates, a popular fruit during Ramadan, could be considered a superfood. A 2002 study discovered that dates may be effective in combating cancer-causing mutations. In a 2009 study, healthy individuals who consumed 100g of dates daily for four weeks showed remarkable results. Despite the sugar content of the Hallawi and Medjool dates, their blood sugar levels remained stable. The research also indicated that dates could potentially inhibit plaque buildup in arteries...

item.title: There is debate over whether mobile phones can cause cancer, with some believing they can and others disagreeing
item.description:
There have been many concerns about mobile phones and cancer risks. Since the first mobile phone’s debut in 1984 and their rise in popularity in the 1990s, it’s taken time to study the long-term effects of mobile phone radiation, as some cancers take years to manifest. We might only now be starting to see the impact. A recent study in Pathophysiology suggests that radiation from mobile and cordless phones could contribute to a specific brain tumor called glioma...
